{{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} [[Image:Lionsoftsavo2008.jpg|thumb|right|275px|The Tsavo Man-Eaters on display in the [[Field Museum of Natural History]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], the [[United States of America]]]] The '''Tsavo Man-Eaters''' were a pair of [[man-eater|man-eating]] [[East African lion|lion]]s in the [[Tsavo]] region, which were responsible for the deaths of a number of [[construction worker]]s on the [[Kenya-Uganda Railway]] between March and December 1898. The significance of this lion pair was their unusual behavior of killing men and the manner of their attacks.
==History== {{multiple image |align=right |direction=vertical |image1=Colonel Patterson with Tsavo-Lion.jpg |caption1=The first lion killed by Patterson, now known as FMNH 23970 |width1=220 |image2=Second Tsavo lion.png |caption2=The second lion, FMNH 23969 |width2=220 }} As part of the construction of a railway linking [[Uganda]] with the [[Indian Ocean]] at [[Kilindini Harbour]], in March 1898 the British started building a railway bridge over the [[Tsavo River]] in [[Kenya]]. The project was led by Lieutenant-Colonel [[John Henry Patterson (author)|John Henry Patterson]]. During the next nine months of construction, two [[Mane (lion)|maneless]] male Tsavo lions stalked the campsite, dragging [[India]]n workers from their tents at night and devouring them. Crews tried to scare off the lions and built campfires and ''[[Boma (enclosure)|bomas]]'', or thorn fences made of [[Acacia drepanolobium|whistling thorn]] trees around their camp for protection to keep the man-eaters out, all to no avail; the lions leaped over or crawled through the thorn fences. After repeated attacks, hundreds of workers fled from Tsavo, halting construction on the bridge. Patterson set traps and tried several times to ambush the lions at night from a tree. After repeated unsuccessful attempts, he shot the first lion on 9 December 1898. Twenty days later, the second lion was found and killed. The first lion killed measured {{convert|9|ft|8|in|m|abbr=on}} from nose to tip of tail. It took eight men to carry the carcass back to camp.
Patterson wrote in his account that he wounded the first lion with one bullet from a high-calibre rifle. This shot struck the lion in its back leg, but it escaped. Later, it returned at night and began stalking Patterson as he tried to hunt it. He shot it through the shoulder, penetrating its heart with a more powerful rifle and found it lying dead the next morning not far from his platform.
The second lion was shot up to nine times, five with the same rifle, three with a second, and once with a third rifle.<ref name=Patterson2>chapter IX The Death of the Second Man-Eater, ''The Man-Eaters of Tsavo and other East African Adventures'' by Lieut.-Col. J. H. Patterson, DSO publication date unknown as recorded on Amazon Kindle{{page needed|date=September 2013}}</ref> The first shot was fired from atop a scaffolding that Patterson had built near a goat killed by the lion. Two shots from a second rifle hit the lion 11 days later as it was stalking Patterson and trying to flee. When they found the lion the next day, Patterson shot it three more times with the same rifle, severely crippling it, and he shot it three times with a third rifle, twice in the chest, and once in the head, which killed it. He claimed it died gnawing on a fallen tree branch, still trying to reach him.<ref name=Patterson2/>
The construction crew returned and finished the bridge in February 1899. The exact number of people killed by the lions is unclear. Patterson gave several figures, overall claiming that there were 135 victims.<ref name=Patterson>{{cite book | author = Patterson, Bruce D. | year = 2004 | title = The Lions of Tsavo: Exploring the Legacy of Africa's Notorious Man-Eaters | publisher = McGraw-Hill | isbn = 0-07-136333-5}}{{page needed|accessdate=23 September 2013|date=August 2017}}</ref><ref name=Borzo>{{cite press release |title=Field Museum uncovers evidence behind man-eating; revises legend of its infamous man-eating lions |url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2003-01/fm-fmu011303.php |publisher=The FIeld Museum |date=2003}}</ref>
After 25 years as Patterson's floor rugs, the lions' skins were sold to the [[Chicago Field Museum]] in 1924 for a sum of $5,000. The skins arrived at the museum in very poor condition. The lions were reconstructed and are now on permanent display along with their skulls.
==Modern research== [[File:Man Eaters of Tsavo Skulls.JPG|thumb|The skulls of the Tsavo Man-Eaters, located in the diorama]] In 2001, a review about causes for man-eating behaviour among lions revealed that the proposed human toll of 100 or more was most likely an exaggeration and that the more likely total was 28–31 victims. This reduced total was based on their review of Colonel Patterson's original journal, courtesy of Alan Patterson.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The science of ‘man-eating’ among lions Panthera leo with a reconstruction of the natural history of the ‘man-eaters of Tsavo’ |author=Kerbis Peterhans, J. C. & Gnoske, T. P. |journal=Journal of East African Natural History |year=2001 |volume=90 |issue=1 |pages=1-40}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Caputo |first=P. |title=Ghosts of Tsavo |page=274 |isbn=0-7922-6362-6}}</ref>
The two lion specimens in Chicago's Field Museum are known as FMNH 23970, the 'crouching' mount, killed on 9 December 1898, and FMNH 23969, the 'standing' mount, killed on 29 December 1898. Recent studies on the [[isotopic signature]] analysis of [[Δ13C]] and [[Nitrogen-15]] in their bone [[collagen]] and hair [[keratin]] were published in 2009. Using realistic assumptions on the consumable tissue per victim, lion energetic needs, and their assimilation efficiencies, researchers compared the man-eaters' Δ13C signatures to various reference standards: Tsavo lions with normal (wildlife) diets, grazers and browsers from Tsavo East and Tsavo West, and the skeletal remains of [[Taita people]] from the early 20th century. Interpolation of their estimates across the 9 months of recorded man-eating behavior suggested that FMNH 23969 ate the equivalent of 10.5 humans and that FMNH 23970 ate 24.2 humans.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1073/pnas.0905309106 |title=Cooperation and individuality among man-eating lions |year=2009 |last1=Yeakel |first1=J. D. |last2=Patterson |first2=B. D. |last3=Fox-Dobbs |first3=K. |last4=Okumura |first4=M. M. |last5=Cerling |first5=T. E. |last6=Moore |first6=J. W. |last7=Koch |first7=P. L. |last8=Dominy |first8=N. J. |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |volume=106 |issue=45 |pages=19040–3 |pmid=19884504 |pmc=2776458}}</ref>
The scientific analysis does not differentiate between entire human corpses consumed, compared to parts of individual prey, since the attacks often raised alarm forcing the lions to slink back into the surrounding area. Many workers over the long construction period went missing, died in accidents, or simply left out of fear; so it is likely almost all of the builders, who stayed on, knew someone missing or supposedly eaten. It appears that Colonel Patterson may have exaggerated his claims as have subsequent investigators (e.g. "135 armed men", Neiburger and Patterson, 2000) though none of these modern studies have taken into account the people who were killed but not eaten by the animals.<ref name=ChiTrib>{{cite news |title= Scientists restate Tsavo lions' taste for human flesh |author= |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=2009 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/chi-tsavo-lions-02-nov02,0,3222846.story | first=K. | last=Janssen}}</ref> The diet of the victims would also affect their [[isotopic signature]]. A low meat diet would produce a signature more typical of herbivores in the victims, affecting the outcome of the test.<ref>{{cite book|doi=10.1021/bk-1984-0258.ch014 |chapter=Models for Carbon Isotope Fractionation Between Diet and Bone |title=Stable Isotopes in Nutrition |series=ACS Symposium Series |year=1984 |last1=Krueger |first1=Harold W. |last2=Sullivan |first2=Charles H. |isbn=0-8412-0855-7 |volume=258 |page=205}}</ref> That fact is important to note since many of the workers at Tsavo were Hindus and may have had a vegetarian diet. This research also excludes, but does not disprove, the claims that the lions were not eating the victims they killed but merely killing just to kill. Similar claims have been made of other wildlife predators.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
==Possible causes of "man-eating" behaviour== Theories for the man-eating behaviour of lions have been reviewed by Peterhans and Gnoske, as well as [[Bruce D. Patterson]] (2004). Their discussions include the following: *An outbreak of [[rinderpest]] (cattle plague) in 1898 devastated the lions' usual prey, forcing them to find alternative food sources. *The Tsavo lions may have been accustomed to finding dead humans at the Tsavo River crossing. Slave caravans to the center of the [[Arab slave trade]], [[Zanzibar]], routinely crossed the river there. *"Ritual invitation", or abbreviated cremation of [[Hindu]] railroad workers, invited scavenging by the lions.
An alternative argument indicates that the first lion had a severely damaged tooth that would have compromised its ability to kill natural prey.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/a/fieldmuseum.org/bruce-pattersons-lab/Home |title=Field Museum |date= |accessdate=2018-07-24}}</ref> This theory has been generally disregarded by the general public and Colonel Patterson, who killed the lions, personally disclaimed it, saying that he damaged that tooth with his rifle while the lion charged him one night, prompting it to flee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lionlamb.us/gandd.html|title=The Tsavo Man-Eaters|work=lionlamb.us}}</ref>
Studies indicate the lions ate humans as a supplement to other food, not as a last resort. Eating humans was probably an alternative to hunting or scavenging caused by dental disease and/or a limited number of prey.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2017/04/man-eating-lions-teeth-kenya/|title=Why Man-Eating Lions Prey on People—New Evidence|date=2017-04-19|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=DeSantis|first=Larisa R. G.|last2=Patterson|first2=Bruce D.|date=2017-04-19|title=Dietary behaviour of man-eating lions as revealed by dental microwear textures|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-00948-5|journal=Scientific Reports|language=En|volume=7|issue=1|pages=904|doi=10.1038/s41598-017-00948-5|pmid=28424462|pmc=5430416|issn=2045-2322}}</ref>
In a 2017 study carried out by the team of Dr. Bruce Patterson it has been found that one of the lions had an infection at the root of his canine tooth, which made it hard for the lion to hunt. Lions normally use their jaws to grab prey like zebras and wildebeests and suffocate them.<ref>{{Cite journal | url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-00948-5 | doi=10.1038/s41598-017-00948-5| pmid=28424462| pmc=5430416| title=Dietary behaviour of man-eating lions as revealed by dental microwear textures| journal=Scientific Reports| volume=7| issue=1| pages=904| year=2017| last1=Desantis| first1=Larisa R. G.| last2=Patterson| first2=Bruce D.}}</ref>
==Popular culture==
===In film=== Patterson's book was the basis for several movies: * ''[[Men Against the Sun]]'' (1952) * ''[[Bwana Devil]]'' (1952) * ''[[Killers of Kilimanjaro]]'' (1956) * ''[[The Ghost and the Darkness]]'' (1996) – a film in which [[Val Kilmer]] plays [[John Henry Patterson (author)|John Henry Patterson]] * ''[[Mrugaraju]]'' (2001) * ''[[Prey (2007 film)|Prey]]'' (2007) *''[[:nl:Prooi_(film)|Prooi]]'' (2016)
===In games=== * The lions appear as a difficulty to be overcome in the "Cape to Cairo" scenario of the video game ''[[Railroad Tycoon II]]''. * Tsavo'ka (translation: Ghost in the Darkness) is a rare tiger that can be found on the Timeless Isle in ''[[World of Warcraft]]''. * In ''[[Cabela's Dangerous Hunts 2011]]'' the lions were mentioned by the character Mbeki to the main character Cole as he was telling him about mysterious animals that have been terrorizing local villages.
===In print=== * ''Ghosts of Tsavo: Stalking the Mystery Lions of East Africa'' (2002) by [[Philip Caputo]]<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Philip Caputo]]|title=''Ghosts of Tsavo: Stalking the Mystery Lions of East Africa'' |publisher='' National Geographic''|edition= First |date=June 1, 2003|isbn= 0792241002}}</ref> * ''The Lions of Tsavo: Exploring the Legacy of Africa's Notorious Man-Eaters'' (2004)<ref>{{cite book|title=The Lions of Tsavo: Exploring the Legacy of Africa's Notorious Man-Eaters|publisher= McGraw-Hill|edition=1 |date=January 22, 2004|author=Bruce Patterson| isbn=0071363335 }}</ref> by [[Field Museum of Natural History]] scientist [https://sites.google.com/a/fieldmuseum.org/bruce-pattersons-lab/Home Bruce D. Patterson]<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://fieldmuseum.org/about/field-museum-scientist-bruce-pattersons-tsavo-lions-research-highlighted-emirates-airlines|journal=Field Museum website's About Us page|title= Field Museum Scientist Bruce Patterson's Tsavo Lions Research Highlighted in Emirates Airline's 'Open Skies'|accessdate=|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110073412/http://fieldmuseum.org/about/field-museum-scientist-bruce-pattersons-tsavo-lions-research-highlighted-emirates-airlines|archive-date=2013-11-10}}</ref> * The plot of the [[Willard Price]] book ''[[Lion Adventure]]'' (1967) was inspired by the man-eaters of Tsavo, wherein [[Hal and Roger Hunt]] are hired to deal with a man-eating lion that is preying on railroad workers. At one point in the book, Hal recounts Colonel Patterson's original tale. * The story of Patterson and the man-eating lions was also an inspiration for the book ''Three Weeks in December'' (2012) by Audrey Schulman.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schulman|first=Audrey|title=Three Weeks in December|year=2012|publisher=Europa Editions|location=New York|isbn=978-1-60945-064-9|page=352|url=http://www.europaeditions.com/book.php?Id=203}}</ref>

{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = World Cancer Day |type = |image = The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = WCD |observedby = [[UN Members]] |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = 4 February |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = |observances = Awareness of [[cancer]] and to encourage its prevention |relatedto = }} '''World Cancer Day''' is an [[international observance#February|international day]] marked on [[:February 4]] to [[raising awareness|raise awareness]] of [[cancer]] and to encourage its [[cancer prevention|prevention]], [[Cancer screening|detection]], and [[treatment of cancer|treatment]]. World Cancer Day was founded by the [[Union for International Cancer Control]] (UICC) to support the goals of the [[World Cancer Declaration]], written in 2008. The primary goal of World Cancer Day is to significantly reduce illness and [[Epidemiology of cancer#Incidence_and_mortality|death caused by cancer]]<ref name="World Cancer Day 2013 Summary">{{cite web|title=World Cancer Day 2013 One-Pager (English)|url=http://www.worldcancerday.org/background-information|publisher=UICC|accessdate=2 February 2013}}</ref> and is an opportunity to rally the international community to end the injustice of preventable suffering from cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/cancer/world-cancer-day/en/|title=World Cancer Day|website=World Health Organization|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref>
World Cancer Day targets misinformation,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/LIFE/usaedition/2013-02-04-World-Cancer-Day-aims-to-dispel-stereotypes_ST_U.htm|title=World Cancer Day targets myths, spreads message|last=Szabo|first=Liz|work=[[USA Today]]|date=3 February 2013|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> raises awareness, and reduces [[social stigma|stigma]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/world-cancer-day-why-is-the-disease-still-a-taboo-a6853126.html|title=World Cancer Day: Why is the disease still a taboo?|last=Gander|first=Kashmira|work=[[The Independent]]|date=4 February 2016|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> Multiple initiatives run on World Cancer Day to show support for those affected by cancer. One of these movements is #NoHairSelfie, a global movement to have "hairticipants" shave their heads either physically or virtually to show a symbol of courage for those undergoing cancer treatment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/three-international-productions-including-scotlands-the-james-plays-to-headline-luminato-2016/article28412339/|title=Three international productions, including Scotland’s The James Plays, to headline Luminato 2016|last=Wheeler|first=Brad|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=27 January 2016|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref> Images of participants are then shared over social media. Hundred of events around the world also take place<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldcancerday.org/map|title=WCD {{!}} We Can. I Can.|website=www.worldcancerday.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref>.
== World Cancer Day themes == In 2016, World Cancer Day started a three-year campaign under the tagline of 'We can. I can.', which explored the power of collective and individual actions to reduce the impact of cancer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldcancerday.org/about/2016-2018-world-cancer-day-campaign|title=World Cancer Day 2016-2018 {{!}} WCD|website=www.worldcancerday.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> Prior to 2016, the campaign themes included "Not Beyond Us" (2015) and "Debunk the Myths" (2014).
2019 will be the start of a new campaign theme. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Theme |- |2016 - 2018 |'We can. I can.' |- |2015 |Not Beyond Us<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uicc.org/world-cancer-day-2015-not-beyond-us-campaign-launched|title=World Cancer Day 2015: 'Not Beyond Us' Campaign launched! {{!}} UICC|website=www.uicc.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> |- |2014 |Debunk the Myths<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.uicc.org/world-cancer-day-2014-debunk-myths|title=World Cancer Day 2014: Debunk the myths! {{!}} UICC|website=www.uicc.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> |- |2013 |Cancer Myths - Get the Facts <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cansa.org.za/cancer-myths-get-the-facts-on-world-cancer-day-4-feb-2013/|title=» Cancer Myths – Get the Facts on World Cancer Day – 4 Feb 2013 {{!}} CANSA – The Cancer Association of South Africa|website=www.cansa.org.za|language=en|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> |- |2012 |Together let's do something<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asbestosdiseaseawareness.org/archives/9464|title=World Cancer Day: "Stand Up To Cancer!" and End Mesothelioma and other Asbestos-Caused Cancers - ADAO - Asbestos Disease Awareness Organization|website=www.asbestosdiseaseawareness.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> |- |2011 |Cancer can be prevented<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/cancer/events/world_cancer_day/en/|title=WHO {{!}} World Cancer Day 2011|website=www.who.int|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> |}

[[Democratic Party (Northern Cyprus)|Democratic Party]] | nationality = Turkish Cypriot }} '''İsmet Kotak''' (1939 – 11 September 2011) was a [[Turkish Cypriot]] politician, public administrator, journalist and columnist. İsmet Kotak was [[Member of Parliament]] (1970–85, 1990–93), [[Minister of Labour]] (1969–76), [[Industry minister|Minister of Industry and Co-operatives]] (1982–83), director-general of the [[Bayrak|Bayrak Radio Television Corporation]], president of [[Cyprus Turkish Press Council|Press Council]] in Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.{{Cite news |url=http://www.kibrissondakika.com/kktc/ismet-kotak-topraga-veriliyor.htm |title=İsmet Kotak toprağa veriliyor |accessdate=2013-03-03 |date=2011-09-12 |language=Turkish |publisher=Kıbrıs Son Dakika}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.basbakanlik.gov.ct.tr/tr-tr/%C3%BCstmenu/ismetkotak.aspx |title=İsmet Kotak |accessdate=2013-03-03 |language=Turkish |publisher=TRNC Prime Ministry |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130419042138/http://www.basbakanlik.gov.ct.tr/tr-tr/%C3%BCstmenu/ismetkotak.aspx |archivedate=2013-04-19 |df= }} He was one of the co-founders of [[Democratic People's Party (Northern Cyprus)|Democratic People's Party]] and founder of the [[Free Democratic Party (Northern Cyprus)|Free Democratic Party]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kotak, Ismet}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:People from Famagusta]] [[Category:Leaders of political parties in Northern Cyprus]] [[Category:Democratic Party (Northern Cyprus) politicians]] [[Category:Turkish Cypriot columnists]] [[Category:Ankara University Faculty of Political Sciences alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from aortic dissection]] [[Category:Date of birth unknown]] {{Cyprus-politician-stub}} {{Journalist-stub}}
